title: About
text:
About this site
This page is my project team name, Kam’s Roast.

title: Project Proposal
text:
Bangkok is one of the fastest-growing cities in Southeast Asia, facing rapid urban expansion, increased infrastructure development, and significant environmental challenges. In response, the Green Bangkok 2030 project was launched to increase green spaces and make the city more livable and sustainable. However, measuring actual progress toward this goal requires objective, data-driven monitoring methods.
Satellite-based remote sensing offers an efficient and scalable way to monitor changes in land cover over time. By using high-resolution temporal data from 2020 to 2024, this study seeks to assess how Bangkok’s urban landscape is evolving—particularly the extent of green space changes. This work is crucial for supporting evidence-based urban planning and evaluating the effectiveness of greening initiatives.

title: Results & Discussion
text: The Buffer tool was used over the wadi_derna_boundary layer to generate a 50m buffer around the banks of the Wadi Derna.

title: Project Proposal
text:
Bangkok is one of the fastest-growing cities in Southeast Asia, facing rapid urban expansion, increased infrastructure development, and significant environmental challenges. In response, the Green Bangkok 2030 project was launched to increase green spaces and make the city more livable and sustainable. However, measuring actual progress toward this goal requires objective, data-driven monitoring methods.
Satellite-based remote sensing offers an efficient and scalable way to monitor changes in land cover over time. By using high-resolution temporal data from 2020 to 2024, this study seeks to assess how Bangkok’s urban landscape is evolving—particularly the extent of green space changes. title: methodology
text:
Bangkok is one of the fastest-growing cities in Southeast Asia, facing rapid urban expansion, increased infrastructure development, and significant environmental challenges. In response, the Green Bangkok 2030 project was launched to increase green spaces and make the city more livable and sustainable. However, measuring actual progress toward this goal requires objective, data-driven monitoring methods.
Satellite-based remote sensing offers an efficient and scalable way to monitor changes in land cover over time. By using high-resolution temporal data from 2020 to 2024, this study seeks to assess how Bangkok’s urban landscape is evolving—particularly the extent of green space changes. This work is crucial for supporting evidence-based urban planning and evaluating the effectiveness of greening initiatives.

title: Methodology
text:
Project Objectives

To detect and classify land cover types (e.g., built-up areas, vegetation, water bodies) in Bangkok using annual high-resolution satellite images from 2020 to 2024.
To quantify the spatial and temporal changes in green spaces and urban development over the study period.
To visualize and analyze patterns of urban expansion or greening using GIS-based maps and change detection techniques.
To evaluate the alignment between observed land cover changes and the targets set by the Green Bangkok 2030 initiative.

title: Overview
text:
Bangkok is rapidly urbanizing, and with this growth comes the challenge of balancing development with environmental sustainability. This project uses high-resolution satellite imagery from Sentinel-2 (or Landsat 8) between 2020 and 2024 to detect land cover changes in Bangkok, with a special focus on green spaces.
By leveraging remote sensing and GIS techniques, this study provides a data-driven view of how Bangkok’s landscape has evolved over five years, supporting the assessment of urban development trends in relation to the city’s Green Bangkok 2030 goals.

title: Overview
text:
Bangkok is rapidly urbanizing, and with this growth comes the challenge of balancing development with environmental sustainability. This project uses high-resolution satellite imagery from Sentinel-2 (or Landsat 8) between 2020 and 2024 to detect land cover changes in Bangkok, with a special focus on green spaces.
By leveraging remote sensing and GIS techniques, this study provides a data-driven view of how Bangkok’s landscape has evolved over five years, supporting the assessment of urban development trends in relation to the city’s Green Bangkok 2030 goals.

title: Overview
text:
Objectives

To classify major land cover types in Bangkok annually from 2020 to 2024.
To quantify the spatial and temporal changes in green spaces and built-up areas.
To visualize land cover transitions and detect urban expansion patterns.
To evaluate how these changes align with the Green Bangkok 2030 initiative.

title: Overview
text:
Tools & Data

Satellite Imagery: Sentinel-2 / Landsat 8 (2020–2024)
GIS Software: QGIS
Methods: Supervised classification, NDVI analysis, change detection

title: Overview
text:
Why It Matters
The results of this project can inform urban planners, policymakers, and researchers about the pace and patterns of land cover change in Bangkok. With green space being a vital component of urban resilience and public health, tracking its progression is critical to shaping a sustainable future for the city.
